verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:760
verses.text: Canon XXXVII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:761
verses.text: Since at different times there have been invasions of barbarians, and therefore very many cities have been subjected to the infidels, so that the bishop of a city may not be able, after he has been ordained, to take possession of his see, and to be settled in it in sacerdotal order, and so to perform and manage for it the ordinations and all things which by custom appertain to the bishop: we, preserving honour and veneration for the priesthood, and in no wise wishing to employ the Gentile injury to the ruin of ecclesiastical rights, have decreed that those who have been ordained thus, and on account of the aforesaid cause have not been settled in their sees, without any prejudice from this thing may be kept [in good standing] and that they may canonically perform the ordination of the different clerics and use the authority of their office according to the defined limits, and that whatever administration proceeds from them may be valid and legitimate.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:762
verses.text: For the exercise of his office shall not be circumscribed by a season of necessity when the exact observance of law is circumscribed.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:763
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:764
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XXXVII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:765
verses.text: A bishop who, on account of the incursions of the barbarians, is not set in his throne, shall have his own chair of state, and shall ordain, and shall enjoy most firmly all the rights of the priesthood.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:766
verses.text: By Canon XVIII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:767
verses.text: of Antioch the principle of this canon was enunciated, that when a bishop did not take possession of his see because he could not do so, he was not to be held responsible or to lose any of his episcopal rights and powers, in that case the impossibility arose from the insubordination of the people, in this from the diocese being in the hands of the barbarians.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:768
verses.text: It has been commonly thought that the Bishops in partibus infidelium had their origin in the state of things calling for this canon.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:769
verses.text: Canon XXXVIII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:770
verses.text: The canon which was made by the Fathers we also observe, which thus decreed: If any city be renewed by imperial authority, or shall have been renewed, let the order of things ecclesiastical follow the civil and public models.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:771
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:772
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XXXVIII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:773
verses.text: If any city is or shall be renewed by the Emperor, the ecclesiastical order shall follow the political and public example.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:774
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:775
verses.text: The canon of the Fathers which the Synod wishes observed is XVII of Chalcedon, the notes on which see.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:776
verses.text: Here it must be noted that by "civil and public models" is signified the "pragmatic" or imperial letters, by which the emperors granted to newly raised up or re-edified towns the privilege of other cities, or else annexed them to some Province.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:777
verses.text: Canon XXXIX.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:778
verses.text: Since our brother and fellow-worker, John, bishop of the island of Cyprus, together with his people in the province of the Hellespont, both on account of barbarian incursions, and that they may be freed from servitude of the heathen, and may be subject alone to the sceptres of most Christian rule, have emigrated from the said island, by the providence of the philanthropic God, and the labour of our Christ-loving and pious Empress; we determine that the privileges which were conceded by the divine fathers who first at Ephesus assembled, are to be preserved without any innovations, viz.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:779
verses.text: : that new Justinianopolis shall have the rights of Constantinople and whoever is constituted the pious and most religious bishop thereof shall take precedence of all the bishops of the province of the Hellespont, and be elected [?] by his own bishops according to ancient custom.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:780
verses.text: For the customs which obtain in each church our divine Fathers also took pains should be maintained, the existing bishop of the city of Cyzicus being subject to the metropolitan of the aforesaid Justinianopolis, for the imitation of all the rest of the bishops who are under the aforesaid beloved of God metropolitan John, by whom, as custom demands, even the bishop of the very city of Cyzicus shall be ordained.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:781
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:782
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XXXIX.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:783
verses.text: The new Justinianopolis shall have the rights of Constantinople, and its prelate shall rule over all the bishops of the Hellespont to whom he has gone, and he shall be ordained by his own bishop: as the fathers of Ephesus decreed.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:784
verses.text: Hefele.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:785
verses.text: Hitherto the bishop of Cyzicus was metropolitan of the province of the Hellespont.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:786
verses.text: Now he too is to be subject to the bishop of New-Justinianopolis.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:787
verses.text: What, however, is meant by "the right of Constantinople"? It was impossible that the Synod should place the bishop of Justinianopolis in equal dignity with the patriarch of Constantinople.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:788
verses.text: But they probably meant to say: "The rights which the bishop of Constantinople has hitherto exercised over the province of the Hellespont, as chief metropolitan, fall now to the bishop of New-Justinianopolis".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:789
verses.text: Or perhaps we should read, instead of Constantinople Κωνσταντινέων πόλεως, as the Amerbachian ms.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:790
verses.text: has it, and translate: "The same rights which Constantia (the metropolis of Cyprus) possessed, New Justinianopolis shall henceforth have".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:791
verses.text: The latter is the more probable.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:792
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:793
verses.text: To understand this canon it must be remembered that the Metropolis of Cyprus, which was formerly called Constantia, when restored by the Emperor Justinian was called by his name, New Justinianopolis.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:794
verses.text: Canon XL.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:795
verses.text: Since to cleave to God by retiring from the noise and turmoil of life is very beneficial, it behoves us not without examination to admit before the proper time those who choose the monastic life, but to observe respecting them the limit handed down by our fathers, in order that we may then admit a profession of the life according to God as for ever firm, and the result of knowledge and judgment after years of discretion have been reached.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:796
verses.text: He therefore who is about to submit to the yoke of monastic life should not be less than ten years of age, the examination of the matter depending on the decision of the bishop, whether he considers a longer time more conducive for his entrance and establishment in the monastic life.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:797
verses.text: For although the great Basil in his holy canons decreed that she who willingly offers to God and embraces virginity, if she has completed her seventeenth year, is to be entered in the order of virgins: nevertheless, having followed the example respecting widows and deaconesses, analogy and proportion being considered, we have admitted at the said time those who have chosen the monastic life.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:798
verses.text: For it is written in the divine Apostle that a widow is to be elected in the church at sixty years old: but the sacred canons have decreed that a deaconess shall be ordained at forty, since they saw that the Church by divine grace had gone forth more powerful and robust and was advancing still further, and they saw the firmness and stability of the faithful in observing the divine commandments.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:799
verses.text: Wherefore we also, since we most rightly comprehend the matter, appoint the benediction of grace to him who is about to enter the struggle according to God, even as impressing speedily a certain seal upon him, hereupon introducing him to the not-long-to-be-hesitated-over and declined, or rather inciting him even to the choice and determination of good.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:800
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:801
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XL.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:802
verses.text: A monk must be ten years old.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:803
verses.text: Even if the Divine Basil thought the one shorn should be over seventeen.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:804
verses.text: But although the Apostle ordains that a widow to be espoused to the Church must be sixty, yet the Fathers say a Deaconess is to be ordained at forty, the Church in the meanwhile having become stronger; so we place the seal on a monk at an earlier age.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:805
verses.text: Aristenus.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:806
verses.text: The eighteenth canon of Basil the Great orders that she who offers herself to the Lord and renounces marriage, ought to be over sixteen or even seventeen years of age: so that her promise may be firm and that if she violates it she may suffer the due penalties.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:807
verses.text: For, says he, children's voices are not to be thought of any value in such matters.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:808
verses.text: But the present canon admits him who is not less than ten years and desires to be a monk, but entrusts the determination of the exact time to the judgment of the hegumenos, whether he thinks it more advantageous to increase the age-requirement for the entering and being established in the married life.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:809
verses.text: But the canon lessens the time defined by Basil the Great, because the Fathers thought that the Church by divine grace had grown stronger since then, and was going on more and more, and that the faithful seemed firmer and more stable for the observance of the divine commandments.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:810
verses.text: And for the same reason, viz.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:811
verses.text: , that the Church was growing better, the sacred canons had lessened the age of deaconesses, and fixed it at forty years, although the Apostle himself orders that no widow is to be chosen into the Church under sixty years of age.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:812
verses.text: Canon XLI.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:813
verses.text: Those who in town or in villages wish to go away into cloisters, and take heed for themselves apart, before they enter a monastery and practise the anchorite's life, should for the space of three years in the fear of God submit to the Superior of the house, and fulfil obedience in all things, as is right, thus shewing forth their choice of this life and that they embrace it willingly and with their whole hearts; they are then to be examined by the superior (προέδρος) of the place; and then to bear bravely outside the cloister one year more, so that their purpose may be fully manifested.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:814
verses.text: For by this they will shew fully and perfectly that they are not catching at vain glory, but that they are pursuing the life of solitude because of its inherent beauty and honour.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:815
verses.text: After the completion of such a period, if they remain in the same intention in their choice of the life, they are to be enclosed, and no longer is it lawful for them to go out of such a house when they so desire, unless they be induced to do so for the common advantage, or other pressing necessity urging on to death; and then only with the blessing of the bishop of that place.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:816
verses.text: And those who, without the above-mentioned causes, venture forth of their convents, are first of all to be shut up in the said convent even against their wills, and then are to cure themselves with fasting and other afflictions, knowing how it is written that "no one who has put his hand to the plough and has looked back, is fit for the kingdom of heaven".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:817
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:818
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XLI.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:819
verses.text: Whoever is about to enter a cloister, let him live for three years in a monastery, and before he is shut up let him spend one year more, and so let him be shut up.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:820
verses.text: And he shall not then go forth unless death or the common good demands.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:821
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:822
verses.text: This canon, so far as it sets forth the necessity of probation before admission to the Anchorite life, synods in after-years frequently approved, taught as they were by experience how perilous a matter it is to admit without sufficient probation to this solitary life and state of separation from the common intercourse with his fellow men.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:837
verses.text: Those who are called Eremites and are clothed in black robes, and with long hair go about cities and associate with the worldly both men and women and bring odium upon their profession—we decree that if they will receive the habit of other monks and wear their hair cut short, they may be shut up in a monastery and numbered among the brothers; but if they do not choose to do this, they are to be expelled from the cities and forced to live in the desert (ἐρήμους) from whence also they derive their name.

verses.text: An eremite dressed in black vesture and not having his hair cut, unless he has his hair cut shall be expelled the city and be shut up in his monastery.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:841
verses.text: It may not be irreverent to remark that this species of impostors always has been common in the East, and many examples will be found of the dervishes in the Arabian Nights and other Eastern tales.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:842
verses.text: The "vagabond" monks of the West also became a great nuisance as well as a scandal in the Middle Ages.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:843
verses.text: The reader will find interesting instances of Spanish deceivers of the same sort in "Gil Blas" and other Spanish romances.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:844
verses.text: Canon XLIII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:845
verses.text: It is lawful for every Christian to choose the life of religious discipline, and setting aside the troublous surgings of the affairs of this life to enter a monastery, and to be shaven in the fashion of a monk, without regard to what faults he may have previously committed.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:846
verses.text: For God our Saviour says: "Whose cometh to me, I will in no wise cast out".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:847
verses.text: As therefore the monastic method of life engraves upon us as on a tablet the life of penitence, we receive whoever approaches it sincerely; nor is any custom to be allowed to hinder him from fulfilling his intention.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:848
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:849
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XLIII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:850
verses.text: Whoever flees from the surging billows of life and desires to enter a monastery, shall be allowed to do so.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:851
verses.text: Zonaras.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:852
verses.text: The greatness or the number of a man's sins ought not to make him lose hope of propitiating the divinity by his penitence, if he turns his eyes to the divine mercy.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:853
verses.text: This is what the canon asserts, and affirms that everyone, no matter how wicked and nefarious his life may have been, may embrace monastic discipline, which inscribes, as on a tablet, to us a life of penitence.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:854
verses.text: For as a tablet describes to us what is inscribed upon it, so the monastic profession writes and inscribes upon us penitence, so that it remains for ever.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:855
verses.text: Canon XLIV.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:856
verses.text: A monk convicted of fornication, or who takes a wife for the communion of matrimony and for society, is to be subjected to the penalties of fornicators, according to the canons.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:857
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:858
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XLIV.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:859
verses.text: A monk joined in marriage or committing fornication shall pay the penalty of a fornicator.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:860
verses.text: The punishment here seems too light, so that Balsamon thinks that this canon only refers to such monks as freely confess their sin and desist from it, remaining in their monasteries; and that the sterner penalties assigned to unchaste religious by other synods (notably Chalcedon, can.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:861
verses.text: xvj.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:862
verses.text: , and Ancyra, can.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:863
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:864
verses.text: ) are for such as do not confess their faults but are after some time convicted of them.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:865
verses.text: Aristenus.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:866
verses.text: The monk will receive the same punishment whether he be a fornicator or has joined himself with a woman for the communion of marriage.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:867
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:868
verses.text: It is very likely from this canon that the Monastic vow at the time of this Synod was not yet an impedimentum dirimens of matrimony, for nothing is said about the dissolution of the marriage contracted by a monk although he had gravely sinned in violating his faith pledged to God.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:869
verses.text: Canon XLV.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:870
verses.text: Whereas we understand that in some monasteries of women those who are about to be clothed with the sacred habit are first adorned in silks and garments of all kinds, and also with gold and jewels, by those who bring them thither, and that they thus approach the altar and are there stripped of such a display of wealth, and that immediately thereafter the blessing of their habit takes place, and they are clothed with the black robe; we decree that henceforth this shall not be done.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:871
verses.text: For it is not lawful for her who has already of her own free will put away every delight of life, and has embraced that method of life which is according to God, and has confirmed it with strong and stable reasons, and so has come to the monastery, to recall to memory the things which they had already forgotten, things of this world which perisheth and passeth away.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:872
verses.text: For thus they raise in themselves doubts, and are disturbed in their souls, like the tossing waves, turning hither and thither.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:873
verses.text: Moreover, they should not give bodily evidence of heaviness of heart by weeping, but if a few tears drop from their eyes, as is like enough to be the case, they may be supposed by those who see them to have flowed μὴ μᾶλλον on account of their affection (διαθέσεως, affectionem) for the ascetic struggle rather than (ἢ) because they are quitting the world and worldly things.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:874
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:875
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XLV.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:876
verses.text: Parents shall not deck out in silks a daughter who has chosen the monastic life, and thus clothe her, for this is a recalling to her mind the world she is leaving.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:877
verses.text: This canon is at the present day constantly broken at the profession of Carmelites.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:878
verses.text: Canon XLVI.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:879
verses.text: Those women who choose the ascetic life and are settled in monasteries may by no means go forth of them.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:880
verses.text: If, however, any inexorable necessity compels them, let them do so with the blessing and permission of her who is mother superior; and even then they must not go forth alone, but with some old women who are eminent in the monastery, and at the command of the lady superior.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:881
verses.text: But it is not at all permitted that they should stop outside.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:882
verses.text: And men also who follow the monastic life let them on urgent necessity go forth with the blessing of him to whom the rule is entrusted.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:883
verses.text: Wherefore, those who transgress that which is now decreed by us, whether they be men or women, are to be subjected to suitable punishments.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:884
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:885
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XLVI.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:886
verses.text: A nun shall not go out of her convent without the consent of her superior, nor shall she go alone but with an older one of the order.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:887
verses.text: It is in no case permitted to her to spend the night outside.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:888
verses.text: The same is the case with a monk; he cannot go out of the monastery without the consent of the superior.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:889
verses.text: Canon XLVII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:890
verses.text: No woman may sleep in a monastery of men, nor any man in a monastery of women.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:891
verses.text: For it behoves the faithful to be without offence and to give no scandal, and to order their lives decorously and honestly and acceptably to God.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:892
verses.text: But if any one shall have done this, whether he be cleric or layman, let him be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:893
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:894
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XLVII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:895
verses.text: It is not allowed that a woman should sleep in a convent of men, nor a man in a monastery of women.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:896
verses.text: The ground covered by this canon is also found in Justinian's Code, Book xliv.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:897
verses.text: , Of Bishops and Clergy.

verses.text: Vide also Novella cxxxiii.

verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:902
verses.text: From the whole context of Justinian's law it is manifest that Justinian here is condemning "double monasteries," in which both men and women dwelt.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:903
verses.text: And he wishes such to be separated, the men from the women, and e contra the women from the men, and that each should dwell in separate monasteries.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:904
verses.text: The reader may be reminded of some curious double religious houses in England for men and women, of which sometimes a woman was the superior of both.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:905
verses.text: Canon XLVIII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:906
verses.text: The wife of him who is advanced to the Episcopal dignity, shall be separated from her husband by their mutual consent, and after his ordination and consecration to the episcopate she shall enter a monastery situated at a distance from the abode of the bishop, and there let her enjoy the bishop's provision.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:907
verses.text: And if she is deemed worthy she may be advanced to the dignity of a deaconess.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:908
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:909
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XLVIII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:910
verses.text: She who is separated from one about to be consecrated bishop, shall enter a monastery after his ordination, situated at a distance from the See city, and she shall be provided for by the bishop.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:911
verses.text: Canon XLIX.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:912
verses.text: Renewing also the holy canon, we decree that the monasteries which have been once consecrated by the Episcopal will, are always to remain monasteries, and the things which belong to them are to be preserved to the monastery, and they cannot any more be secular abodes nor be given by any one to seculars.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:913
verses.text: But if anything of this kind has been done already, we declare it to be null; and those who hereafter attempt to do so are to be subjected to canonical penalties.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:914
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:915
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XLIX.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:916
verses.text: Monasteries built with the consent of the bishop shall not afterwards be turned into secular houses, nor shall they pass into the hands of seculars.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:917
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:918
verses.text: This canon renews canon xxiv.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:919
verses.text: of Chalcedon.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:920
verses.text: And here it may be observed that the canons even of Ecumenical Synods fall into desuetude little by little, unless the care of bishops and pastors keeps them alive, and from the example of this synod it may be seen how often they need calling back again into observance.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:921
verses.text: Nor can there be any doubt that frequently it would be more advantageous to renew the canons already set forth by the Fathers, rather than to frame new ones.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:922
verses.text: Canon L.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:923
verses.text: No one at all, whether cleric or layman, is from this time forward to play at dice.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:924
verses.text: And if any one hereafter shall be found doing so, if he be a cleric he is to be deposed, if a layman let him be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:925
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:926
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon L.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:927
verses.text: A layman should not play at dice.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:928
verses.text: This renews canons xlii.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:929
verses.text: and xliij.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:930
verses.text: of the Apostolic canons.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:931
verses.text: Canon LI.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:932
verses.text: This holy and ecumenical synod altogether forbids those who are called "players," and their "spectacles," as well as the exhibition of hunts, and the theatrical dances.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:933
verses.text: If any one despises the present canon, and gives himself to any of the things which are forbidden, if he be a cleric he shall be deposed, but if a layman let him be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:934
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:935
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LI.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:936
verses.text: Whose shall play as an actor or shall attend theatrical representations or hunts shall be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:937
verses.text: Should he be a cleric he shall be deposed.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:938
verses.text: Balsamon.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:939
verses.text: Some one will enquire why canon xxiiij.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:940
verses.text: decrees that those in holy orders and monks, who are constantly attending horse-races, and scenic plays, are to cease or be deposed: but the present canon says without discrimination, that those who give themselves over to such things if clergymen are to be deposed, and if laymen to be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:941
verses.text: The solution is this.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:942
verses.text: It is one thing and more easily to be endured, that a man should be present at a horse-race, or be convicted of going to see a play; and another thing, and one that cannot be pardoned, that he should give himself over to such things, and to exercise this continually as his business.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:943
verses.text: Wherefore those who have once sinned deliberately, are admonished to cease.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:944
verses.text: If they are not willing to obey, they are to be deposed.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:945
verses.text: But those who are constantly engaged in this wickedness, if they are clerics, they must be deposed from their clerical place, if laymen they must be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:946
verses.text: Canon LII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:947
verses.text: On all days of the holy fast of Lent, except on the Sabbath, the Lord's day and the holy day of the Annunciation, the Liturgy of the Presanctified is to be said.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:948
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:949
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:950
verses.text: Throughout the whole of Lent except upon the Lord's day, the Sabbath, and upon the day of the Annunciation, the presanctified gifts shall be offered.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:951
verses.text: Balsamon.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:952
verses.text: We do not call the service of the Presanctified the unbloody sacrifice, but the offering of the previously offered, and of the perfected sacrifice, and of the completed priestly act.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:953
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:954
verses.text: The Greeks therefore confess that the bread once offered and consecrated, is not to be consecrated anew on another day; but a new offering is made of what was before consecrated and presanctified: just as in the Latin Church the consecrated or presanctified bread of Maundy Thursday is offered on Good Friday.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:955
verses.text: The Patriarch Michael of Constantinople is quoted by Leo Allatius as saying that "none of the mystic consecratory prayers are said over the presanctified gifts, but the priest only recites the prayer that he may be a worthy communicant".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:956
verses.text: Some among the later Greeks have been of opinion that the unconsecrated wine was consecrated by the commixture with the consecrated bread, and (without any words of consecration) was transmuted into the sacred blood, and with this seems to agree the already quoted Michael, Patriarch of Constantinople, who is cited by Leo Allatius in his treatise on the rite of the presanctified.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:957
verses.text: "The presanctified is put into the mystic chalice, and so the wine which was then in it, is changed into the holy blood of the Lord".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:958
verses.text: And with this agrees Simeon, Archbishop of Thessalonica, in his answer to Gabriel of Pentapolis, when he writes: "In the mass of the Presanctified no consecration of what is in the chalice is made by the invocation of the Holy Spirit and of his sign, but by the participation and union of the life-giving bread, which is truly the body of Christ".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:959
verses.text: From this opinion, which was held by some of the Greeks, it gradually became the practice at Constantinople not to dip the bread in the Sacred Blood, as Michael the patriarch of this very church testifies.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:960
verses.text: But in the ordinary Euchologion of the Greeks it is expressly set forth that the presanctified bread before it is reserved, should be dipped in the sacred blood, and for this a rite is provided.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:961
verses.text: Leo Allatius's Dissertatio de Missa Praesanctificatorum should be read; an outline of the service as found in the Euchologion, and as reprinted by Renaudotius is as follows.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:962
verses.text: First of all vespers is said.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:963
verses.text: After some lessons and prayers, including the "Great Ectenia" and that for the Catechumens, these are dismissed.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:964
verses.text: After the Catechumens have departed there follows the Ectenia of the Faithful.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:965
verses.text: After which, "Now the heavenly Powers invisibly minister with us; for, behold, the King of Glory is borne in.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:966
verses.text: Behold the mystic sacrifice having been perfected is borne aloft by angels.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:967

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:971
verses.text: "For the precious and presanctified gifts that are offered, let us pray to the Lord.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:972
verses.text: "That our man-loving God, etc".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:973
verses.text: as in the ordinary liturgy past the Lord's prayer, and down to the Sancta Sanctis, which reads as follows:  Priest.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:974
verses.text: Holy things presanctified for holy persons.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:975
verses.text: Choir.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:976
verses.text: One holy, one Lord Jesus Christ, to the Glory of God the Father—Amen.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:977
verses.text: Then the Communion Hymn and the Communion, and the rest as in the ordinary liturgy, except "this whole evening," is said for "this whole day," and another prayer is provided in the room of that beginning "Lord, who blessest them, etc".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:978
verses.text: It is curious to note that on Good Friday, the only day on which the Mass of the Presanctified is celebrated in the West, its use has died out in the East, and now it is used "on the Wednesdays and Fridays of the first six weeks of the Great Quadragesima, on the Thursday of the fifth week, and on the Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday of Holy Passion Week.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:979
verses.text: It may also be said, excepting on Saturdays and Sundays, and on the Festival of the Annunciation, on other days during the Fast, to wit, on those of festivals and their Vigils, and on the Commemoration of the Dedication of the Church".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:980
verses.text: Symeon, who was bishop of Thessalonica, and flourished in the early part of the XVth Century, complains of the general neglect of the Mass of the Presanctified on Good Friday in his time, and says that his church was the only one in the Exarchate that then retained it.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:981
verses.text: He ascribes the disuse to the example of the Church of Jerusalem.

verses.text: Canon LIII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:992
verses.text: Whereas the spiritual relationship is greater than fleshly affinity; and since it has come to our knowledge that in some places certain persons who become sponsors to children in holy salvation-bearing baptism, afterwards contract matrimony with their mothers (being widows), we decree that for the future nothing of this sort is to be done.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:993
verses.text: But if any, after the present canon, shall be observed to do this, they must, in the first place, desist from this unlawful marriage, and then be subjected to the penalties of fornicators.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:996
verses.text: Godfathers cannot be permitted to be married with the mother of their godchildren.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:997
verses.text: If any one is so joined, let him do penance after separation.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1000
verses.text: )  The imperial law forbade the adopter parent to marry his or her adopted son or daughter; for the godchild was thought a sort of an adopted child.

verses.text: Van Espen however refers, and to my mind with greater truth, to Justinian's law (xxvj of the Cod.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1008
verses.text: de Nuptiis) which forbids the marriage of a man with his nurse or with whoever received him from the font, "because," says the law, "nothing can so incite to parental affection, and therefore induce a just prohibition of marriage, than a bond of this sort by which, through God's meditation, their souls are bound together".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1009
verses.text: Canon LIV.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1010
verses.text: The divine scriptures plainly teach us as follows, "Thou shalt not approach to any that is near of kin to thee to uncover their nakedness".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1011
verses.text: Basil, the bearer-of-God, has enumerated in his canons some marriages which are prohibited and has passed over the greater part in silence, and in both these ways has done us good service.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1012
verses.text: For by avoiding a number of disgraceful names (lest by such words he should pollute his discourse) he included impurities under general terms, by which course he shewed to us in a general way the marriages which are forbidden.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1013
verses.text: But since by such silence, and because of the difficulty of understanding what marriages are prohibited, the matter has become confused; it seemed good to us to set it forth a little more clearly, decreeing that from this time forth he who shall marry with the daughter of his father; or a father or son with a mother and daughter; or a father and son with two girls who are sisters; or a mother and daughter with two brothers; or two brothers with two sisters, fall under the canon of seven years, provided they openly separate from this unlawful union.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1014
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LIV.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1015
verses.text: Thou shalt not permit the marriage of a son of a brother to the daughter of a brother; nor with a daughter and her mother shall there be the marriage of a son and his father; neither a mother and a daughter with two brothers; nor brothers with two sisters.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1016
verses.text: But should anything of this sort have been done, together with separation, penance shall be done for seven years.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1017
verses.text: Canon LV.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1018
verses.text: Since we understand that in the city of the Romans, in the holy fast of Lent they fast on the Saturdays, contrary to the ecclesiastical observance which is traditional, it seemed good to the holy synod that also in the Church of the Romans the canon shall immovably stands fast which says: "If any cleric shall be found to fast on a Sunday or Saturday (except on one occasion only) he is to be deposed; and if he is a layman he shall be cut off".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1019
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1020
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LV.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1021
verses.text: The Romans fast the Sabbaths of Lent.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1022
verses.text: Therefore this Synod admonishes that upon these days the Apostolical canon is of force.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1023
verses.text: The canon quoted is LXVI.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1026
verses.text: The Fathers of this Synod thought that this canon of the Apostles was edited by the Apostles themselves, and therefore they seem to have reprobated the custom of the Roman Church of fasting on the Sabbath more bitterly than was right.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1027
verses.text: Whence it happens this is one of those canons which the Roman Church never received.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1028
verses.text: Zonaras.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1029
verses.text: The synod took in hand to correct this failing (σφάλμα) of the Latins; but until this time they have arrogantly remained in their pertinacity, and so remain to-day.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1030
verses.text: Nor do they heed the ancient canons which forbid fasting on the Sabbath except that one, to wit the great Sabbath, nor are they affected by the authority of this canon.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1031
verses.text: Moreover the clerics have no regard for the threatened deposition, nor the laymen for their being cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1032
verses.text: Canon LVI.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1033
verses.text: We have likewise learned that in the regions of Armenia and in other places certain people eat eggs and cheese on the Sabbaths and Lord's days of the holy lent.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1034
verses.text: It seems good therefore that the whole Church of God which is in all the world should follow one rule and keep the fast perfectly, and as they abstain from everything which is killed, so also should they from eggs and cheese, which are the fruit and produce of those animals from which we abstain.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1035
verses.text: But if any shall not observe this law, if they be clerics, let them be deposed; but if laymen, let them be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1036
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1037
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LVI.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1038
verses.text: Armenians eat eggs and cheese on the Sabbaths in Lent.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1039
verses.text: It is determined that the whole world should abstain from these.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1040
verses.text: If not let the offender be cast out.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1041
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1042
verses.text: This canon shows that the ancient Greeks, although they did not fast on the Sabbaths and Lord's days of Lent, nevertheless they abstained on them from flesh food; and it was believed by them that abstinence from flesh food involved also necessarily abstinence from all those things which have their origin from flesh.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1043
verses.text: This also formerly was observed by the Latins in Lent, and in certain regions is known still to be the usage.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1044
verses.text: Canon LVII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1045
verses.text: It is not right to offer honey and milk on the altar.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1046
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1047
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LVII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1048
verses.text: No one should offer honey or milk at the altar.

verses.text: The Greeks apparently do not recognize the exception specified in the canon of the African Code.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1054
verses.text: Canon LVIII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1055
verses.text: None of those who are in the order of laymen may distribute the Divine Mysteries to himself if a bishop, presbyter, or deacon be present.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1056
verses.text: But whoso shall dare to do such a thing, as acting contrary to what has been determined shall be cut off for a week and thenceforth let him learn not to think of himself more highly than he ought to think.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1057
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1058
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LVIII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1059
verses.text: A layman shall not communicate himself.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1060
verses.text: Should he do so, let him be cut off for a week.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1061
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1062
verses.text: It is well known that in the first centuries it was customary that the Holy Eucharist should be taken back by the faithful to their houses; and that at home they received it at their own hands.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1063
verses.text: It is evident that this was what was done by the Anchorites and monks who lived in the deserts, as may be seen proved by Cardinal Bona.

verses.text: From this domestic communion it is easily seen how the abuse arose which is condemned in this canon.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1071
verses.text: Canon LIX.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1072
verses.text: Baptism is by no means to be administered in an oratory which is within a house; but they who are about to be held worthy of the spotless illumination are to go to a Catholic Church and there to enjoy this gift.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1073
verses.text: But if any one shall be convicted of not observing what we have determined, if he be a cleric let him be deposed, if a layman let him be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1074
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LIX.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1075
verses.text: In oratories built in houses they shall not celebrate baptism.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1076
verses.text: Whoever shall not observe this, if a cleric he shall be deposed, if a layman he shall be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1077
verses.text: Canon LX.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1078
verses.text: Since the Apostle exclaims that he who cleaves to the Lord is one spirit, it is clear that he who is intimate with his [i-e: the Lord's] enemy becomes one by his affinity with him.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1079
verses.text: Therefore, those who pretend they are possessed by a devil and by their depravity of manners feign to manifest their form and appearance; it seems good by all means that they should be punished and that they should be subjected to afflictions and hardships of the same kind as those to which they who are truly demoniacally possessed are justly subjected with the intent of delivering them from the [work or rather] energy of the devil.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1080
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1081
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LX.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1082
verses.text: Whoever shall pretend to be possessed by a devil, shall endure the penance of demoniacs.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1083
verses.text: Zonaras says in his scholion that even in his day people made the same claim to diabolical possession.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1084
verses.text: Canon LXI.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1085
verses.text: Those who give themselves up to soothsayers or to those who are called hecatontarchs or to any such, in order that they may learn from them what things they wish to have revealed to them, let all such, according to the decrees lately made by the Fathers concerning them, be subjected to the canon of six years.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1086
verses.text: And to this [penalty] they also should be subjected who carry about she-bears or animals of the kind for the diversion and injury of the simple; as well as those who tell fortunes and fates, and genealogy, and a multitude of words of this kind from the nonsense of deceit and imposture.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1087
verses.text: Also those who are called expellers of clouds, enchanters, amulet-givers, and soothsayers.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1088
verses.text: And those who persist in these things, and do not turn away and flee from pernicious and Greek pursuits of this kind, we declare are to be thrust out of the Church, as also the sacred canons say.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1089
verses.text: "For what fellowship hath light with darkness?" as saith the Apostle, "or what agreement is there between the temple of God and idols? or what part hath he that believeth with an infidel? And what concord hath Christ with Belial?"  Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1090
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXI.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1091
verses.text: Whoever shall deliver himself over to a hecatontarch or to devils, so as to learn some secret, he shall be put under penance for six years.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1092
verses.text: So too those who take around a bear, who join themselves with those who seek incantations and drive away the clouds, and have faith in fortune and fate, shall be cast out of the assembly of the Church.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1093
verses.text: Hefele.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1099
verses.text: They sold the hair [of these she bears and other animals] as medicine or for an amulet.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1103
verses.text: Chrysostom in his Homilies on the Statutes explains, in answer to certain who defended them on this ground, that if these incantations are made in the name of Christ they are so much the worse.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1104
verses.text: The Saint says, "Moreover I think that she is to be hated all the more who abuses the name of God for this purpose, because while professing to be a Christian, she shows by her actions that she is a heathen".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1105
verses.text: Canon LXII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1106
verses.text: The so-called Calends, and what are called Bota and Brumalia, and the full assembly which takes place on the first of March, we wish to be abolished from the life of the faithful.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1107
verses.text: And also the public dances of women, which may do much harm and mischief.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1108
verses.text: Moreover we drive away from the life of Christians the dances given in the names of those falsely called gods by the Greeks whether of men or women, and which are performed after an ancient and un-Christian fashion; decreeing that no man from this time forth shall be dressed as a woman, nor any woman in the garb suitable to men.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1109
verses.text: Nor shall he assume comic, satyric, or tragic masks; nor may men invoke the name of the execrable Bacchus when they squeeze out the wine in the presses; nor when pouring out wine into jars [to cause a laugh], practising in ignorance and vanity the things which proceed from the deceit of insanity.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1110
verses.text: Therefore those who in the future attempt any of these things which are written, having obtained a knowledge of them, if they be clerics we order them to be deposed, and if laymen to be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1111
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1112
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1113
verses.text: Let these be taken away from the lives of the faithful, viz.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1114
verses.text: : the Bota, and the Calends, and the Brumalia, and salutations in honour of the gods, and comic, satyric and tragic masks, and the invocation of Bacchus at the wine press, and the laughing at the wine jars.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1115
verses.text: Whoever shall persist in these after this canon shall be liable to give an account.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1116
verses.text: On the Calends see Du Cange (Glossarium in loc.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1118
verses.text: The Bota were feasts in honour of Pan, the Brumalia feasts in honour of Bacchus.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1119
verses.text: Many particulars with regard to these superstitions will be found in Balsamon's scholion, to which the curious reader is referred.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1120
verses.text: Van Espen also has some valuable notes on the Kalends of January.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1121
verses.text: Canon LXIII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1122
verses.text: We forbid to be publicly read in Church, histories of the martyrs which have been falsely put together by the enemies of the truth, in order to dishonour the martyrs of Christ and induce unbelief among those who hear them, but we order that such books be given to the flames.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1123
verses.text: But those who accept them or apply their mind to them as true we anathematize.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1124
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1125
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXIII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1126
verses.text: Martyrologies made up by the ethnics (῾Ελλη νιών) shall not be published in church.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1127
verses.text: What is condemned is false histories of true martyrs, not (as Johnson erroneously supposes) "false legends of pretended martyrs".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1128
verses.text: There have been martyrs, both royal and plebeian, in much later times whose lives have been made ridiculous and whose memory has been rendered hateful to the ignorant people by so-called "histories" which might well have received the treatment ordered by the canon.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1129
verses.text: Canon LXIV.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1130
verses.text: It does not befit a layman to dispute or teach publicly, thus claiming for himself authority to teach, but he should yield to the order appointed by the Lord, and to open his ears to those who have received the grace to teach, and be taught by them divine things; for in one Church God has made "different members," according to the word of the Apostle: and Gregory the Theologian, wisely interpreting this passage, commends the order in vogue with them saying: "This order brethren we revere, this we guard.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1131
verses.text: Let this one be the ear; that one the tongue, the hand or any other member.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1132
verses.text: Let this one teach, but let that one learn".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1133
verses.text: And a little further on: "Learning in docility and abounding in cheerfulness, and ministering with alacrity, we shall not all be the tongue which is the more active member, not all of us Apostles, not all prophets, nor shall we all interpret".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1134
verses.text: And again: "Why dost thou make thyself a shepherd when thou art a sheep? Why become the head when thou art a foot? Why dost thou try to be a commander when thou art enrolled in the number of the soldiers?" And elsewhere: "Wisdom orders, Be not swift in words; nor compare thyself with the rich, being poor; nor seek to be wiser than the wise".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1135
verses.text: But if any one be found weakening the present canon, he is to be cut off for forty days.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1136
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1137
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXIV.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1138
verses.text: A layman shall not teach, for all are not prophets, nor all apostles.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1139
verses.text: Zonaras points out that this canon refers only to public instruction and not to private.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1140
verses.text: Van Espen further notes that in the West this restriction is limited to the solemn and public preaching and announcing of the Word of God, which is restricted to bishops, and only by special and express license given to the other clergy, and refers to his own treatment of the subject In jure Eccles.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1146
verses.text: Canon LXV.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1147
verses.text: The fires which are lighted on the new moons by some before their shops and houses, upon which (according to a certain ancient custom) they are wont foolishly and crazily to leap, we order henceforth to cease.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1148
verses.text: Therefore, whosoever shall do such a thing, if he be a cleric, let him be deposed; but if he be a layman, let him be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1149
verses.text: For it is written in the Fourth Book of the Kings "And Manasses built an altar to the whole host of heaven, in the two courts of the Lord, and made his sons to pass through the fire, he used lots and augurs and divinations by birds and made ventriloquists [or pythons] and multiplied diviners, that he might do evil before the Lord and provoke him to anger".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1150
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1151
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXV.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1152
verses.text: The fires which were made upon the new moons at the workshops are condemned and those who leaped upon them.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1153
verses.text: Lupin remarks that the fires kindled on certain Saints' days are almost certainly remains of this heathen practice.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1154
verses.text: These fires are often accompanied with leaping, drinking, and the wrestling of young men.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1155
verses.text: Canon LXVI.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1156
verses.text: From the holy day of the Resurrection of Christ our God until the next Lord's day, for a whole week, in the holy churches the faithful ought to be free from labour, rejoicing in Christ with psalms and hymns and spiritual songs; and celebrating the feast, and applying their minds to the reading of the holy Scriptures, and delighting in the Holy Mysteries; for thus shall we be exalted with Christ and together with him be raised up.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1157
verses.text: Therefore, on the aforesaid days there must not be any horse races or any public spectacle.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1158
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1159
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXVI.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1160
verses.text: The faithful shall every one of them go to church during the whole week after Easter.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1161
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1162
verses.text: It is certain that the whole of Easter week was kept as a feast by the whole Church both East and West; and this Synod did not introduce this custom by its canon, but adopted this canon to ensure its continuance.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1163
verses.text: Here we have clearly set forth the Christian manner of passing a feast-day, viz.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1164
verses.text: , that the faithful on those days did give themselves up to "Psalms and Hymns and Spiritual Songs," from which the divine office which we call today canonical [i-e:, chiefly Mattins and Vespers] are made up; and hence we understand that all the faithful ought to attend the choir-offices, which was indeed observed for many centuries, as I have shewn in my Dissertation on the Canonical Hours, cap.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1165
verses.text: III.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1166
verses.text: , § 1, and therefore it was called "public" [or common] prayer.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1167
verses.text: Canon LXVII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1168
verses.text: The divine Scripture commands us to abstain from blood, from things strangled, and from fornication.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1169
verses.text: Those therefore who on account of a dainty stomach prepare by any art for food the blood of any animal, and so eat it, we punish suitably.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1170
verses.text: If anyone henceforth venture to eat in any way the blood of an animal, if he be a clergyman, let him be deposed; if a layman, let him be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1171
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1172
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXVII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1173
verses.text: A cleric eating blood shall be deposed, but a layman shall be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1174
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1175
verses.text: The apostolic precept of abstaining "from blood and from things strangled" for some ages, not only among the Greeks but also among the Latins, was observed in many churches, but little by little and step by step it died out in the whole Church, at least in the Latin Church, altogether.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1176
verses.text: In this the Latin Church followed the opinion of St.

verses.text: Augustine, Contra Faustum Manichaeum, Lib.

verses.text: , where he teaches at great length that the precept was given to Christians only while the Gentile Church was not yet settled.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1182
verses.text: This passage of Augustine also proves that at that time Africa did not observe this precept of the Apostles.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1183
verses.text: Canon LXVIII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1184
verses.text: It is unlawful for anyone to corrupt or cut up a book of the Old or New Testament or of our holy and approved preachers and teachers, or to give them up to the traders in books or to those who are called perfumers, or to hand it over for destruction to any other like persons: unless to be sure it has been rendered useless either by bookworms, or by water, or in some other way.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1185
verses.text: He who henceforth shall be observed to do such a thing shall be cut off for one year.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1186
verses.text: Likewise also he who buys such books (unless he keeps them for his own use, or gives them to another for his benefit to be preserved) and has attempted to corrupt them, let him be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1187
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1188
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXVIII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1189
verses.text: Thou shalt not destroy nor hand over copies of the Divine Scriptures to be destroyed unless they are absolutely useless.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1190
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1191
verses.text: (Foot-note.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1192
verses.text: )  I think that this canon was directed against certain Nestorian and Eutychian heretics, who, that they might find some patronage of their errors from the Holy Scriptures, dared in the sixth century most infamously to corrupt certain passages of the New Testament.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1193
verses.text: Canon LXIX.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1194
verses.text: It is not permitted to a layman to enter the sanctuary (Holy Altar, Gk.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1195
verses.text: ), though, in accordance with a certain ancient tradition, the imperial power and authority is by no means prohibited from this when he wishes to offer his gifts to the Creator.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1196
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1197
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXIX.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1198
verses.text: No layman except the Emperor shall go up to the altar.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1199
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1200
verses.text: That in the Latin Church as well as in the Greek for many centuries it was the constant custom, ratified by various councils, that lay-men are to be excluded from the sanctuary and from the place marked off for the priests who are celebrating the divine mysteries, is so notorious as to need no proof, and the present canon shows that among the Greeks the laity were not admitted to the sacrarium even to make offerings.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1201
verses.text: The Synod makes but one exception, to wit, the Emperor, who can enter the rails of the holy altar by its permission "when he wishes to offer his gifts to the Creator, according to ancient custom".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1202
verses.text: Not without foundation does the Synod claim "ancient custom" for this; for long before, it is evident, it was the case from the words of the Emperor Theodosius the Younger.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1251

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1307
verses.text: As we confess the divine birth of the Virgin to be without any childbed, since it came to pass without seed, and as we preach this to the entire flock, so we subject to correction those who through ignorance do anything which is inconsistent therewith.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1308
verses.text: Wherefore since some on the day after the holy Nativity of Christ our God are seen cooking σεμίδαλῖν , and distributing it to each other, on pretext of doing honour to the puerperia of the spotless Virgin Maternity, we decree that henceforth nothing of the kind be done by the faithful.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1309
verses.text: For this is not honouring the Virgin (who above thought and speech bare in the flesh the incomprehensible Word) when we define and describe, from ordinary things and from such as occur with ourselves, her ineffable parturition.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1310
verses.text: If therefore anyone henceforth be discovered doing any such thing, if he be a cleric let him be deposed, but if a layman let him be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1313
verses.text: Whoever after the feast of the Mother of God shall prepare σεμίδιλιν (semilam) or anything else on account of what is called puerperia, let him be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1314
verses.text: As the Catholic Church has always taught the Virgin-birth as well as the Virgin-conception of our Blessed Lord, and has affirmed that Mary was ever-virgin, even after she had brought forth the incarnate Son, so it follows necessarily that there could be no childbed nor puerperal flux.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1315
verses.text: It need hardly be remarked here that besides other texts that of the prophet is considered as teaching thus much, "Behold the Virgin (ha alma) shall conceive and bear a son," she that "bare" as well as she that "conceived" being a virgin.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1316

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1318

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1338
verses.text: Whereas we have heard that in some places in the hymn Trisagion there is added after "Holy and Immortal," "Who was crucified for us, have mercy upon us," and since this as being alien to piety was by the ancient and holy Fathers cast out of the hymn, as also the violent heretics who inserted these new words were cast out of the Church; we also, confirming the things which were formerly piously established by our holy Fathers, anathematize those who after this present decree allow in church this or any other addition to the most sacred hymn; but if indeed he who has transgressed is of the sacerdotal order, we command that he be deprived of his priestly dignity, but if he be a layman or monk let him be cut off.

verses.text: We have received from the Scriptures that in the mouth of two or three witnesses every word shall be established.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1401
verses.text: Therefore we decree that slaves who are manumitted by their masters in the presence of three witnesses shall enjoy that honour; for they being present at the time will add strength and stability to the liberty given, and they will bring it to pass that faith will be kept in those things which they now witness were done in their presence.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1405

verses.text: But Zonaras had this same text, and therefore it may be safely followed instead of that of Balsamon, as edited by Beveridge.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1411
verses.text: Canon LXXXVII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1412
verses.text: She who has left her husband is an adulteress if she has come to another, according to the holy and divine Basil, who has gathered this most excellently from the prophet Jeremiah: "If a woman has become another man's, her husband shall not return to her, but being defiled she shall remain defiled;" and again, "He who has an adulteress is senseless and impious".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1413
verses.text: If therefore she appears to have departed from her husband without reason, he is deserving of pardon and she of punishment.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1414
verses.text: And pardon shall be given to him that he may be in communion with the Church.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1415
verses.text: But he who leaves the wife lawfully given him, and shall take another is guilty of adultery by the sentence of the Lord.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1416
verses.text: And it has been decreed by our Fathers that they who are such must be "weepers" for a year, "hearers" for two years, "prostrators" for three years, and in the seventh year to stand with the faithful and thus be counted worthy of the Oblation [if with tears they do penance].

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1417
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1418
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXXXVII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1419
verses.text: She who goes from her husband to another man is an adulteress.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1420
verses.text: And he who from his wife goes to another woman is an adulterer according to the word of the Lord.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1421

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1426
verses.text: Here discipline is relaxed; formerly an adulteress did fifteen years' penance.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1431

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1432
verses.text: Canon LXXXVIII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1433
verses.text: No one may drive any beast into a church except perchance a traveller, urged thereto by the greatest necessity, in default of a shed or resting-place, may have turned aside into said church.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1434
verses.text: For unless the beast had been taken inside, it would have perished, and he, by the loss of his beast of burden, and thus without means of continuing his journey, would be in peril of death.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1435
verses.text: And we are taught that the Sabbath was made for man: wherefore also the safety and comfort of man are by all means to be placed first.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1436
verses.text: But should anyone be detected without any necessity such as we have just mentioned, leading his beast into a church, if he be a cleric let him be deposed, and if a layman let him be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1437
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXXXVIII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1438
verses.text: Cattle shall not be led into the holy halls, unless the greatest necessity compels it.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1439
verses.text: Canon LXXXIX.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1440
verses.text: The faithful spending the days of the Salutatory Passion in fasting, praying and compunction of heart, ought to fast until the midnight of the Great Sabbath: since the divine Evangelists, Matthew and Luke, have shewn us how late at night it was [that the resurrection took place], the one by using the words ὀΨὲ σαββάτων, and the other by the words ὄρθρου βαθέος.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1441
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXXXIX.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1442
verses.text: On the Great Sabbath the fast must be continued until midnight.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1443
verses.text: Canon XC.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1444
verses.text: We have received from our divine Fathers the canon law that in honour of Christ's resurrection, we are not to kneel on Sundays.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1445
verses.text: Lest therefore we should ignore the fulness of this observance we make it plain to the faithful that after the priests have gone to the Altar for Vespers on Saturdays (according to the prevailing custom) no one shall kneel in prayer until the evening of Sunday, at which time after the entrance for compline, again with bended knees we offer our prayers to the Lord.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1446
verses.text: For taking the night after the Sabbath, which was the forerunner of our Lord's resurrection, we begin from it to sing in the spirit hymns to God, leading our feast out of darkness into light, and thus during an entire day and night, we celebrate the Resurrection.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1447
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1448
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XC.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1449
verses.text: From the evening entrance of the Sabbath until the evening entrance of the Lord's day there must be no kneeling.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1450
verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1451
verses.text: No doubt the synod by the words "we have received from the divine Fathers," referred to canon xx.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1452
verses.text: of the Council of Nice.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1453
verses.text: For many centuries this custom was preserved even in the Latin Church; and the custom of keeping feasts and whole days generally from evening to evening is believed to have been an Apostolic tradition, received by them from the Jews.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1454
verses.text: At the end of the VIIIth Century the Synod of Frankfort declared in its xxj.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1457
verses.text: Those who give drugs for procuring abortion, and those who receive poisons to kill the foetus, are subjected to the penalty of murder.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1458
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1459

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1465
verses.text: And we pay no attention to the subtile distinction as to whether the foetus was formed or unformed.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1466
verses.text: And by this not only is justice satisfied for the child that should have been born, but also for her who prepared for herself the snares, since the women very often die who make such experiments".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1468
verses.text: The holy synod decrees that those who in the name of marriage carry off women and those who in any way assist the ravishers, if they be clerics, they shall lose their rank, but if they be laymen they shall be anathematized.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1469
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1470
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XCII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1471
verses.text: Those who run away with women, and those who assist and give a hand, if they be clerics they shall be deposed, if laymen they shall be anathamatized.

verses.text: Van Espen.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1473
verses.text: This canon simply renews and confirms Canon xxvij of Chalcedon.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1474
verses.text: Canon XCIII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1475
verses.text: If the wife of a man who has gone away and does not appear, cohabit with another before she is assured of the death of the first, she is an adulteress.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1476
verses.text: The wives of soldiers who have married husbands who do not appear are in the same case; as are also they who on account of the wanderings of their husbands do not wait for their return.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1477
verses.text: But the circumstance here has some excuse, in that the suspicion of his death becomes very great.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1478
verses.text: But she who in ignorance has married a man who at the time was deserted by his wife, and then is dismissed because his first wife returns to him, has indeed committed fornication, but through ignorance; therefore she is not prevented from marrying, but it is better if she remain as she is.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1479
verses.text: If a soldier shall return after a long time, and find his wife on account of his long absence has been united to another man, if he so wishes, he may receive his own wife [back again], pardon being extended in consideration of their ignorance both to her and to the man who took her home in second marriage.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1480
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1481
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XCIII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1482
verses.text: A woman who when her husband does not turn up, before she is certain he is dead, takes another commits adultery.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1483
verses.text: But when the man returns he may receive her again, if he so elects.

verses.text: ) supposes that to swear by the false gods of the Gentiles, contains in itself some idolatry, an opinion shared by St.
