verses.text: Basil, comparing those using such oaths with them who betrayed Christ, and who are partakers of the talk of devils.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1508
verses.text: Canon XCV.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1509
verses.text: Those who from the heretics come over to orthodoxy, and to the number of those who should be saved, we receive according to the following order and custom.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1510
verses.text: Arians, Macedonians, Novatians, who call themselves Cathari, Aristeri, and Testareskaidecatitae, or Tetraditae, and Apollinarians, we receive on their presentation of certificates and on their anathematizing every heresy which does not hold as does the holy Apostolic Church of God: then first of all we anoint them with the holy chrism on their foreheads, eyes, nostrils, mouth and ears; and as we seal them we say—"The seal of the gift of the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1511
verses.text: But concerning the Paulianists it has been determined by the Catholic Church that they shall by all means be rebaptized.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1512
verses.text: The Eunomeans also, who baptize with one immersion; and the Montanists, who here are called Phrygians; and the Sabellians, who consider the Son to be the same as the Father, and are guilty in certain other grave matters, and all the other heresies—for there are many heretics here, especially those who come from the region of the Galatians—all of their number who are desirous of coming to the Orthodox faith, we receive as Gentiles.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1513
verses.text: And on the first day we make them Christians, on the second Catechumens, then on the third day we exorcise them, at the same time also breathing thrice upon their faces and ears; and thus we initiate them, and we make them spend time in church and hear the Scriptures; and then we baptize them.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1514
verses.text: And the Manichaeans, and Valentinians and Marcionites and all of similar heresies must give certificates and anathematize each his own heresy, and also Nestorius, Eutyches, Dioscorus, Severus, and the other chiefs of such heresies, and those who think with them, and all the aforesaid heresies; and so they become partakers of the holy Communion.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1515
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1516
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XCV.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1517
verses.text: Thus we admit those converted from the heretics.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1518
verses.text: We anoint with the holy chrism, upon the brow, eyes, nostrils, mouth, and ears, Arians, Macedonians, Novatians (who are called Cathari), Aristerians (who are called Quartadecimans or Tetraditae), and Apollinarians when they anathematize every heresy; and sign them with the cross as we say, "The Seal of the gift of the Holy Ghost, Amen".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1519
verses.text: Compare with this Canon vij.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1520
verses.text: of Laodicea, and the so-called vijth.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1521
verses.text: canon of the First Council of Constantinople.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1522
verses.text: The text I have translated is that ordinarily given, I now present to the reader Hefele's argument for its worthlessness.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1523
verses.text: Hefele.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1524
verses.text: This text is undoubtedly false, for (a) the baptism of the Gnostics was, according to the recognized ecclesiastical principle, invalid, and a Gnostic coming into the Church was required to be baptized anew; (b) besides, it would have us first to require of a Gnostic an anathema on Nestorius, Eutyches, etc.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1525
verses.text: More accurate, therefore, is the text, as it is given by Beveridge, and as Balsamon had it, to the effect that: "In the same way (as the preceding) are the Manichaeans, Valentinians, Marcionites, and similar heretics to be treated (i-e:, to be baptized anew); but the Nestorians must (merely) present certificates, and anathematize their heresy, Nestorius, Eutyches, etc".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1526
verses.text: Here we have only this mistake, that the Nestorians must anathematize, among others, also Eutyches, which they would certainly have done very willingly.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1527
verses.text: At the best, we must suppose that there is a gap in the text, and that after, "all of similar heresies," we must add "the later heretics must present certificates and anathematize Nestorius, Eutyches, etc".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1528
verses.text: There seems but little doubt that whatever may be the truth in the matter, the early theologians and fathers held that even though the external rite of Holy Baptism might be validly performed by schismatics and heretics, yet that by it the person so baptized did not receive the Holy Ghost, and this opinion was not confined to the East, but was also prevalent in the West.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1529
verses.text: Vide Rupertus, De Divinis Officiis, Lib.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1533
verses.text: Canon XCVI.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1534
verses.text: Those who by baptism have put on Christ have professed that they will copy his manner of life which he led in the flesh.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1535
verses.text: Those therefore who adorn and arrange their hair to the detriment of those who see them, that is by cunningly devised intertwinings, and by this means put a bait in the way of unstable souls, we take in hand to cure paternally with a suitable punishment: training them and teaching them to live soberly, in order that having laid aside the deceit and vanity of material things, they may give their minds continually to a life which is blessed and free from mischief, and have their conversation in fear, pure, [and holy]; and thus come as near as possible to God through their purity of life; and adorn the inner man rather than the outer, and that with virtues, and good and blameless manners, so that they leave in themselves no remains of the left-handedness of the adversary.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1536
verses.text: But if any shall act contrary to the present canon let him be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1537
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1538
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XCVI.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1539
verses.text: Whoever twist up their hair into artistic plaits for the destruction of the beholders are to be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1540
verses.text: For the intricate manner of dressing the hair used in the East, and for a description of the golden dye, see the scholion of Zonaras.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1541
verses.text: Van Espen remarks that the curious care for somebody else's hair in the form of wigs, so prevalent with many laymen and ecclesiastics of his day, is the same vice condemned by the canon in another shape.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1542
verses.text: Canon XCVII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1543
verses.text: Those who have commerce with a wife or in any other manner without regard thereto make sacred places common, and treat them with contempt and thus remain in them, we order all such to be expelled, even from the dwellings of the catechumens which are in the venerable temples.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1544
verses.text: And if any one shall not observe these directions, if he be a cleric let him be deposed, but if a layman let him be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1545
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1546
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XCVII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1547
verses.text: Whoever in a temple has commerce with his wife and remains there out of contempt, shall be expelled even from the Catechumens.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1548
verses.text: If any one shall not observe this he shall be deposed or cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1549
verses.text: Zonaras.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1550
verses.text: In the name of holy places, not the church itself but the adjoining and dependent buildings are intended such as those which are called the "Catechumena".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1551
verses.text: For no one would be audacious enough to wish to cohabit with his wife in the very temple itself.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1552
verses.text: Canon XCVIII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1553
verses.text: He who brings to the intercourse of marriage a woman who is betrothed to another man who is still alive, is to lie under the charge of adultery.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1554
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1555
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XCVIII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1556
verses.text: He is an adulterer who takes one espoused to some one else.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1557
verses.text: Aristenus's commentary on this canon is Σαφής.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1558
verses.text: A more extraordinary estimate of it could hardly be made.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1559
verses.text: So far from the meaning being "perspicuous," as the Latin translation has it, the meaning seems to be past finding out; for, as Van Espen remarks, a man who sins with a betrothed woman is certainly not an "adulterer".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1560
verses.text: He tries therefore to introduce the idea that though he is not an adulterer, yet he is to be punished as if he were.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1561
verses.text: But the Greek hardly seems patient of this meaning, and the Ancient Epitome says in so many words that he is an adulterer.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1562
verses.text: On account of this difficulty some have supposed that the espousals here mentioned were not de futuro but de proesenti, and that therefore it was the case of stealing a real wife of another man.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1563
verses.text: But this explanation also is involved in many difficulties.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1564
verses.text: Canon XCIX.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1565
verses.text: We have further learned that, in the regions of the Armenians, certain persons boil joints of meat within the sanctuary and offer portions to the priests, distributing it after the Jewish fashion.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1566
verses.text: Wherefore, that we may keep the church undefiled, we decree that it is not lawful for any priest to seize the separate portions of flesh meat from those who offer them, but they are to be content with what he that offers pleases to give them; and further we decree that such offering be made outside the church.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1567
verses.text: And if any one does not thus, let him be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1571

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1572

verses.text: "Let thine eyes behold the thing which is right," orders Wisdom, "and keep thine heart with all care".

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1579
verses.text: For the bodily senses easily bring their own impressions into the soul.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1580
verses.text: Therefore we order that henceforth there shall in no way be made pictures, whether they are in paintings or in what way so ever, which attract the eye and corrupt the mind, and incite it to the enkindling of base pleasures.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1581
verses.text: And if any one shall attempt to do this he is to be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1586
verses.text: The great and divine Apostle Paul with loud voice calls man created in the image of God, the body and temple of Christ.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1587
verses.text: Excelling, therefore, every sensible creature, he who by the saving Passion has attained to the celestial dignity, eating and drinking Christ, is fitted in all respects for eternal life, sanctifying his soul and body by the participation of divine grace.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1588
verses.text: Wherefore, if any one wishes to be a participator of the immaculate Body in the time of the Synaxis, and to offer himself for the communion, let him draw near, arranging his hands in the form of a cross, and so let him receive the communion of grace.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1589
verses.text: But such as, instead of their hands, make vessels of gold or other materials for the reception of the divine gift, and by these receive the immaculate communion, we by no means allow to come, as preferring inanimate and inferior matter to the image of God.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1590
verses.text: But if any one shall be found imparting the immaculate Communion to those who bring vessels of this kind, let him be cut off as well as the one who brings them.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1593
verses.text: Whoever comes to receive the Eucharist holds his hands in the form of a cross, and takes it with his mouth; whoever shall prepare a receptacle of gold or of any other material instead of his hand, shall be cut off.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1617
verses.text: It behoves those who have received from God the power to loose and bind, to consider the quality of the sin and the readiness of the sinner for conversion, and to apply medicine suitable for the disease, lest if he is injudicious in each of these respects he should fail in regard to the healing of the sick man.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1618
verses.text: For the disease of sin is not simple, but various and multiform, and it germinates many mischievous offshoots, from which much evil is diffused, and it proceeds further until it is checked by the power of the physician.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1619
verses.text: Wherefore he who professes the science of spiritual medicine ought first of all to consider the disposition of him who has sinned, and to see whether he tends to health or (on the contrary) provokes to himself disease by his own behaviour, and to look how he can care for his manner of life during the interval.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1620
verses.text: And if he does not resist the physician, and if the ulcer of the soul is increased by the application of the imposed medicaments, then let him mete out mercy to him according as he is worthy of it.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1621
verses.text: For the whole account is between God and him to whom the pastoral rule has been delivered, to lead back the wandering sheep and to cure that which is wounded by the serpent; and that he may neither cast them down into the precipices of despair, nor loosen the bridle towards dissolution or contempt of life; but in some way or other, either by means of sternness and astringency, or by greater softness and mild medicines, to resist this sickness and exert himself for the healing of the ulcer, now examining the fruits of his repentance and wisely managing the man who is called to higher illumination.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1622
verses.text: For we ought to know two things, to wit, the things which belong to strictness and those which belong to custom, and to follow the traditional form in the case of those who are not fitted for the highest things, as holy Basil teaches us.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1623
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CII.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1624
verses.text: The character of a sin must be considered from all points and conversion expected.

verses.name: Council of Trullo 1:1625
verses.text: And so let mercy be meted out.
